rename.from: REST interface for provisioning device identities and tenant information
rename.to: REST interface for provisioning device identities and client authorities

rename.from: REST interface for provisioning device identities and client authorities
rename.to: AMQP endpoint for provisioning device identities and client authorities

body:
I came across some open issues while implementing the registration endpoint. For the Telemetry API we dropped the `device-id` and `tenant-id` properties in favor of providing these in the `to` field. I think to be consistent across our API we should do the same for the Registration API (and for other future APIs). That means to register/deregister a device we have a `to` field of `registration/<tenant-id>/<device-id>`.
And another question concerning the qos level/settle mode: should we handle invalid messages the same way as we do for telemetry messages (forcibly closing the link)? Or should we use the `rejected` state in this case? And does this mean we do not allow pre-settled message for the registration endpoint?

I'm currently thinking about which restrictions we should impose based on the registered devices. For example is a device that is unknown to Hono able to upload telemetry data? Or is it registered automatically the first time it sends data? What do you think?
I think that Hono should refuse to receive data for an unknown device. All devices need to be provisioned before telemetry data or commands can be uploaded to Hono for a device.

Coming back to a previous question of yours:

> And another question concerning the qos level/settle mode: should we handle invalid messages the same way as we do for telemetry messages (forcibly closing the link)? Or should we use the rejected state in this case? And does this mean we do not allow pre-settled message for the registration endpoint?

I think that for the registration API we will _only_ want to support unsettled messages, i.e. we should support _at least once_ delivery only in order to make sure that a client's registration request has been accepted or not. The other question is whether we want to use the disposition to indicate the outcome of the registration itself, i.e. "registration succeed" vs. "registration failed". I guess this would be the easiest way to implement it, in particular if we do not want to persist registration requests before processing them. On the other hand this basically implies a "blocking" API which we generally do not want to have, or do we?

My opinion is that something like a registration mechanism is an "offline" operation in a lot of scenario; it means that we should store registration requests. We may have a "blocking" API using the disposition for success or not but it could be important to distinguish between registration and enabling. After the request to the registration API, a device can be registered immediately but it doesn't mean that it can send data immediately; someone or some rules need to enable it to do so.

Agree with @sophokles73 on supporting only unsettled messages; when a device sends a registration request, it has some interest to know if the request was received and the related result.

rename.from: AMQP endpoint for provisioning device identities and client authorities
rename.to: AMQP endpoint for provisioning device identities
